G.L. c. 186, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Plaintiff Jessica Brown (		"Plaintiff") brings this action against Defendant Mark Thompson (		"Defendant"), seeking damages and equitable relief arising from Defendant																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under Massachusetts law, as codified in G.L. c. 186, ����������������������������������������������������������������������������������������

G.L. c. 231, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 231, ���������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������(sic), as the damages sought exceed the threshold amount for claims within the jurisdiction of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Venue is proper under G.L. c. 223, ������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������, as the property at issue is located in Chelsea, Suffolk County, Massachusetts, and the actions giving rise to this complaint occurred within this judicial district.

*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Indus., Inc.*,.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized a landlord
*Dartt v. Browning-Ferris Indus., Inc.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion is entirely about handicap discrimination under G.L. c. 151B and related evidentiary and jury-instruction issues. It does not discuss landlord-tenant law, landlords’ duties, or any principle about Massachusetts courts recognizing a landlord duty or doctrine. Therefore it cannot support the stated landlord-related proposition.

*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..raw_text: *King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass. 658, 661 (1977)
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized a landlord
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..support_reasoning: The proposition is incomplete, but appears to be invoking a supposed long‑standing Massachusetts recognition of some landlord duty. King does the opposite historically: it explains that *previously* Massachusetts followed a narrow, tenant-specific “Massachusetts rule” and only in this case (building on Lindsey and Hemingway) adopts a broader, general duty of reasonable care for common areas. Thus, it does not show that Massachusetts courts have “long recognized” such a duty; rather, it marks a change from the prior rule.
*King v. G & M Realty Corp.*, 373 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “In the past it was the law of the Commonwealth that a landlord had no general obligation to exercise reasonable care in keeping safe the common areas of an apartment building or similar structure for use by his tenants and their visitors. Rather he was under a separate and limited duty… This was a singular Massachusetts rule; the ‘weight of authority’ was otherwise and imposed on the landlord the general, continuing duty mentioned.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant																																																																																																																																																																																																																																																											 constitutes a violation of Massachusetts law governing quiet enjoyment. See, e.g., *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273, 285 (1994).
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant’s conduct constitutes a violation of Massachusetts quiet enjoyment law, and cites Doe as authority. In Doe, the SJC held that a landlord may be liable under G.L. c. 186, § 14 where its failure to take reasonable measures to address unlawful third-party activity in common areas causes a serious interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment of the premises. The court reversed summary judgment on the quiet enjoyment claim specifically so that a fact-finder could determine whether the landlord’s omissions constituted such a violation, thereby clearly supporting the cited proposition as a matter of law when similar facts are proven.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “We do believe, however, that if the defendant has failed to take any measures, especially those measures which can be undertaken relatively easily, to remove unwelcome persons from the property that it owns and controls, and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Miller v. Shanahan*, 386 Mass. 302, 305.proposition: Defendant																																																																																																																																																																																												created unsafe conditions that directly caused the theft of Plaintiff																																																							's property and placed Plaintiff in fear for her safety. See *Miller v. Shanahan*, 386 Mass. 302, 305 (1982).
*Miller v. Shanahan*, 386 Mass. 302, 305.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the constitutionality of a municipal ordinance prohibiting public drinking and possession of opened containers of alcohol. It does not address tort liability, creation of unsafe conditions, theft of property, or placing a plaintiff in fear for her safety. The cited case is therefore not relevant authority for the proposition about defendant-caused unsafe conditions leading to theft and fear.
*Miller v. Shanahan*, 386 Mass. 302, 305.relevant_excerpt: The defendant was charged with violating c. 14, § 14-29, of the Fitchburg General Ordinances, making it a criminal offense either to drink any alcoholic beverage or to possess “an opened container full or partially full of any alcoholic beverages, while on, in, or upon any public way, upon any way to which the public has right of access, in any place in which members of the public have access as invitees or licensees.” … On these facts, we hold that the ordinance survives a broad facial constitutional attack.

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant																																																																																			's conduct is egregious in light of his continued refusal to address these security concerns, despite repeated notice from Plaintiff. See *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196, 201 (1979).
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The proposition describes a defendant’s *egregious* conduct based on a continued refusal to address security concerns after repeated notice. Berman & Sons concerns a landlord’s strict liability for breach of the implied warranty of habitability and explicitly notes there was insufficient evidence of intentional, negligent, or bad‑faith conduct; the court emphasizes that fault or bad faith are not required. It does not characterize the landlord’s conduct as egregious or focus on repeated refusal to remedy conditions, so it does not support the proposition as framed.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability… The landlord’s lack of fault and reasonable efforts to repair do not prolong the duty to pay full rent. … [T]he warranty of habitability is not designed to penalize the landlord for misbehavior.”

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 92-93.raw_text: *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 92-93 (1982) (describing the damages available for breach of quiet enjoyment)
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 92-93.proposition: Plaintiff has suffered financial loss, emotional distress, and a loss of enjoyment of her tenancy as a direct and proximate result of Defendant																																																																																		's breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 92-93 (1982) (describing the damages available for breach of quiet enjoyment).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 92-93.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the types of damages available for a landlord’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, including emotional distress and loss of enjoyment of the tenancy. Simon v. Solomon squarely addresses damages under G.L. c. 186, §14 (the statutory quiet enjoyment remedy), holding that “actual and consequential damages” for interference with quiet enjoyment encompass personal injuries such as emotional distress, and explaining that this statute was intended to expand traditional quiet enjoyment damages. The case thus supports citing it for the proposition that financial loss, emotional distress, and loss of enjoyment are recoverable as damages for such a breach, even though the specific $10,000 quiet-enjoyment award there was vacated as duplicative.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 92-93.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 provides that tenants may recover ‘actual and consequential’ damages from landlords who have interfered with their quiet enjoyment of leased premises. We have noted that this provision was intended to expand the damages recoverable for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… Generally, ‘actual damages’ are losses flowing directly from a wrongful act… ‘Consequential damages’ cover all losses that are reasonably foreseeable… The combination in § 14 of both actual and consequential damages… suggests that the Legislature intended to include all reasonably foreseeable losses — personal as well as economic — within the scope of statutory recovery.”
